text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: T_ may be able to do it all in one day. I’m not a big fan of all in one day. Uh, just because, uh, it’s got a lot of hoops, and if you don’t have it. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that the tube itself is going to make a channel that has to be in the six-week time so that the channel can sort of get wide enough so that pee comes out, okay. And that’s why they are worried about shall we take it out, shall we not take it out, you should have left it in. And if it’s obstructed it’s got to come out or your kidney function gets bad again. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And that’s why they’re saying it needs to be changed every four to six weeks so that it doesn’t get blocked. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so now the issue is they’re going to probably be doing a lot of voiding trials to see whether or not you can pee on your own. You know do they clamp it and you feel like okay I’ve got to pee and then you can sort of see if you can get it out. So that’s what the urologists are going to be doing. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So on the clinical study, we do scan him more than he would get if he was not on the clinical trial because we’re giving you more therapy than what’s usual, and they wouldn’t want us to keep giving you drugs that they’re not helping, and so they They want the actual data about scans. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So that would be a potential good thing for you. If you want more information, the study gives you more of that information. Family Member: Right. Doctor: But how I make decisions, I don’t necessarily need those scans.

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So again, we kind of ran through the gamut, you know, you need some sort of chemo. So, you know, we talked last time the chemo was just ready to go, just chemo chemo. Then we have the chemo that's a trial with regular chemo versus a pill version. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: Now, that's not the first time we've done a pill version. It's the first time we've done it for this chemo. But like, there's an all time chemotherapy called FIVFU, that they made a pill version of that called Xeloda. So that's an active practice if you have like colon cancer, it's just not something we routinely use for prostate, but the idea has been around so it's not super novel, but we've never done it for this type of chemotherapy. So if it works, it's Patient: So is this what you want to put me on? Doctor: Yes, because the other one and just for timing wise, the other one is also fine with chemo, but the vitamin C, that's high dose. So again, natural but still high doses requires IV. You're here twice a week, every week sort of indefinitely. So it's a big time sink. So I kind of wanted to at least offer you the less intensive one, but also So I think very effective. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And one of the things about trials is we know if it doesn't work, we'll know literally month to month because we're going to check that PSA, we know that that's sort of a good indicator for you Patient: Right, right. Family Member 3: So if it’s not coming down- Doctor: Right Family Member 3: -you'll switch to something else? Doctor: Correct. And you know that this, you know, the oral chemo is not a placebo. I mean, this is like-

text: Patient: Yes, understand. Doctor: So that’s important that we get the pulmonary evaluation, what they’re thinking. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: It’s likely that we probably need new pictures to sort of see what your liver is doing. And I think it’s time in some ways because you know the Enzalutamide is not controlling your PSA, and you’re ARV7 positive it’s likely that if we got more pictures we would see more cancer. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: I need to know what’s going on with your lungs because some of the treatments that we would talk about have toxicity to the lungs as one of the main side effects. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I think he’s mentioned in his note a standard option for you go to would be to chemotherapy. So chemotherapy in someone like you after hormones haven’t worked well enough or long enough; Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: chemotherapy shrinks the PSA for a while, shrinks the tumor for a while in about forty/fifty percent of people. So almost half the people get some benefit from chemotherapy. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We usually know after three or four cycles as to whether or not it’s gonna help, and we keep going. Family Member: Mm, hmm.

text: Patient: No chemo drug, though? Doctor: It is more of a natural product, biologic drug that on, um, in animals and in cell lines looks active against prostate cancer. And, so, now they’re escalating the dose of this natural product. Um. Family Member: Is that, uh, a stem cell or cell therapy or is it a -- Doctor: No, it comes like from a, I--I’d have to look. Whether it comes from a seed cucumber or-- Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Or a pine co—Oh, it’s—I’d have to look it up. But, it’s, it’s a natural thing that, that, they have --- Patient: It’s organic medicine. Doctor: Right. You know, we’ve done studies with pomegranates and muscadine grapes, and it sort of extends to that sort of area. Uh, but this again is, uh, experimental. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um. So, in that study, we’re looking at how you tolerate it. Uh, what’s the safe dose. Ah, and then, you know, we monitor your disease; that if it’s not getting better, then we move on. If it is improving or not - stable, you can stay with that treatment. Patient: Okay. Family Member: It’s a phase one. How long does the phase one run for? Uh, because I’m wondering if there are subsequent phases, um but Doctor: So, typically, we treat three men at a one-dose level.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
